description:
Torque teno virus 6 (TTV-6) is a small, non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus that belongs to the Anelloviridae family. It is one of the numerous genotypes within the Torque teno virus (TTV) species, which is a widely prevalent group of viruses found in various vertebrate hosts, including humans.

TTV-6 is classified as a member of the Alphatorquevirus genus within the Anelloviridae family. The viral genome of TTV-6 consists of a circular, negative-sense, single-stranded DNA molecule, approximately 3.8 to 3.9 kilobases in length. The genome encodes several open reading frames (ORFs) responsible for the production of viral proteins, including the viral capsid and regulatory proteins.

TTV-6, like other TTV genotypes, is known for its high genetic diversity and global distribution. It has been detected in various human populations worldwide, with prevalence rates ranging from 10% to over 90%, depending on the geographic region and the detection methods used.

Despite its widespread presence, the clinical significance of TTV-6 infection remains a subject of ongoing research. While some studies have suggested potential associations between TTV-6 and certain clinical conditions, the exact role of this virus in human health and disease is not yet fully understood. Further research is needed to elucidate the potential pathogenic mechanisms and the immunological interactions between TTV-6 and the host.
